title: SB 237
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 30652 of the Food and Agricultural Code is amended to specify the allocation of fees and fines collected for dog license tags. The funds are to be used for various purposes including issuance of tags, enforcement of division ordinances, compensation for livestock damages caused by dogs, animal emergency care costs, and training for animal control officers. Section 830.9 of the Penal Code is also amended. Section 830.9 of the Penal Code is amended to allow animal control officers to exercise powers of arrest and serve warrants if they complete a specified training course, excluding firearm training if their agency prohibits it. Animal control officers appointed before July 1, 2016, must complete a training course on powers of arrest and serving warrants by July 1, 2017. Firearms training is not required if the employing agency prohibits it. Officers who completed the training before January 1, 2016, are considered to have met the requirements. Every animal control officer appointed after July 1, 2016, must complete a training course on powers of arrest and serving warrants within one year of appointment. This requirement also applies to directors, managers, and supervisors of animal control agencies. Firearms training is not mandatory if the employing agency prohibits it. During each three-year period, animal control officers must complete 40 hours of continuing education sponsored by accredited institutions or associations. Animal control officers appointed before July 1, 2016, must comply with paragraph (1) requirements by July 1, 2019, and every three years thereafter. Officers appointed after July 1, 2016, must comply within three years of appointment and every three years thereafter. Continuing education and training for animal control officers must include at least four hours of course work in powers of arrest and serving warrants taught by a certified instructor. Records of training must be kept by the officer's employing agency. Continuing education and training for animal control officers must include at least four hours of course work in powers of arrest and serving warrants taught by a certified instructor. Records of training shall be maintained by the officer's employing agency. Failure to complete training within 90 days after the expiration of each three-year period will result in immediate suspension of authority. Firearms training includes various types of guns. This section does not apply to animal control officers who are peace officers. The act mandates reimbursement to local agencies and school districts for costs determined by the Commission on State Mandates.
